thread.title: The latest: British Airways' Boeing 777 catches fire in Las Vegas
thread.title_full: The latest: British Airways' Boeing 777 catches fire in Las Vegas

title: The latest: British Airways' Boeing 777 catches fire in Las Vegas
text:
An engine on the British Airways plane caught fire before takeoff, forcing passengers to escape on emergency slides. (Photo: Eric Hays, AP)
Tags Boeing 393 CONNECT 39 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE A British Airways Boeing 777-200 plane was evacuated just before takeoff from Las Vegas on Tuesday after an engine on the Boeing 777-200 caught fire.
USA TODAY's Bart Jansen has the full recap , but â€“ in case you missed the story that developed overnight, here are the highlights:
Video captured a dramatic scene that included smoke billowing from the aircraft, which was operating as British Airways Flight 2776 to London Gatwick.
Airport firefighters reached the plane about two minutes after the flames were reported and had extinguished the fire just a few minutes later. In the meantime, BA's cabin crew was lauded for a brisk but "orderly" evacuation that got all of the flight's passengers off the plane via emergency exit chutes in a matter of minutes.
Smoke spews from British Airways Flight 2276 en route to London's Gatwick Airport at McCarran International Airport in Las Vegas. Media reports indicate that the Boeing 777's engine caught fire and that all 159 passengers and 13 crew were evacuated with just two minor injuries reported. Bradley Hampton , Twitter via European PressPhoto Fullscreen An engine on the British Airways plane caught fire before takeoff, forcing passengers to escape on emergency slides. Eric Hays, AP Fullscreen Firefighters enter a plane that caught fire at McCarren International Airport on Tuesday, Sept. 8, 2015, in Las Vegas. John Locher, AP Fullscreen Casinos along the Las Vegas Strip can be seen behind a plane that caught fire at McCarren International Airport in Las Vegas. John Locher, AP Fullscreen Firefighters stand by a plane that caught fire at McCarren International Airport in Las Vegas. John Locher, AP Fullscreen Like this topic? You may also like these photo galleries: Replay Autoplay Show Thumbnails Show Captions Last Slide Next Slide "Everybody did their job," Flight 2776 passenger Karen Bravo says to the Las Vegas Review-Journal . She also commended airport staff and first responders, suggesting their response to the emergency "could be a training video."
Fire officials told The Associated Press 14 people were treated for injuries, many of which occurred as passengers used exit slides to reach slide to the ground.
BA's latest statement on the incident came Wednesday morning.
"All customers have been provided with hotel accommodation, and our colleagues are helping them with anything further they require," the airline says in a statement released at about 6:45 a.m. ET. "Customers who were taken to hospital have all been released following care and treatment. The National Transportation Safety Board in the US is conducting an investigation into the incident and we will give them our fullest support."
